div.head: Necessary and Sufficient Conditions for Passivity of the LuGre Friction Model
Nikita Barabanov and Romeo Ortega
div.p: Abstract-Friction is a nonlinear phenomenon difficult to describe analytically. To capture its effect in mechanical systems, a bristle-based dynamical model, known as the LuGre model, was recently proposed in the literature. It is difficult to assess whether this (or any other) mathematical model constitutes a bona fide friction model. It should, however, reflect the dissipative nature of friction, which mathematically translates into the requirement of defining a passive operator from velocity to friction force. In this note, we give necessary and sufficient conditions for this property to hold for the LuGre model. The conditions are expressed in terms of a simple algebraic inequality involving the parameters of the model. If this inequality does not hold, we construct an input signal that generates a periodic orbit along which the passivity inequality is violated.
Index Terms-Friction models, nonlinear systems, passive systems.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: It is well known that one of the major limitations to achieving good performance in mechanical systems is the presence of friction, which is a nonlinear phenomenon difficult to describe analytically. Different models have been proposed to capture this phenomenon, starting with the classical descriptions via static maps between velocity and friction force. However, it appears that classical models are unable to capture some of the behavior experimentally observed in systems subject to strong friction effects. It is argued in [1] that dynamic models are necessary to describe the friction phenomena accurately. For a review of some of the existing dynamic friction models, see [1], [8], and references cited therein.

A numerical example for which the passivity condition is violated is presented in [6]. In the latter reference, the following analysis is carried out. To simulate the scenario of a simple (unitary) mass with friction, the friction model above is placed in closed-loop with an integrator, i.e., _ u = 0y. For the resulting second-order dynamical system, it is then shown that there exists a positive definite function whose derivative is strictly positive in some nonempty subset of the state space provided some condition on the friction parameters is satisfied. Unfortunately this fact does not allow us to make any claim about passivity of the operator-nor of stability of the system for that matter-whose rigourous analytical proof remained an open issue. It is interesting, however, to point out that the condition of [6] exactly coincides with the necessary and sufficient condition for passivity that we derive below.

In this note, we provide a complete answer to this question. Specifically, we give necessary and sufficient conditions for the passivity property to hold. The conditions are expressed in terms of a simple algebraic inequality involving the parameters of the model. If this inequality does not hold, we construct an input signal that generates a periodic orbit along which the passivity inequality is violated.

div.head: III. CONCLUSION
div.p: We have provided a conclusive answer to the question of passivity of the generalyzed LuGre friction model (1.1), (1.2), (2.1), and (2.2). Namely, we have shown that the model defines a passive operator if and only if the coefficients satisfy the inequality (2.4). We have furthermore shown that, if the inequality is strict, the operator is actually input strictly passive.

It is interesting to try to check the passivity condition (2.4) in a real application. To this end, let us consider the experimental setup (consisting of a DC motor connected to a gearbox with significant friction) installed in the Laboratoire d'Automatique de Grenoble, (see [8] for a detailed description). The identified parameters of the friction model (1.1)-(1.3) are [0; 1; 2; 0; 1; v0] > = [260; 0:6; 0:0176; 0:28; 0:05; 0:01] > :

Unfortunately, the key passivity inequality (2.4) is not satisfied for these data. Since the difference is of an order of magnitude (i.e., 0:0176 < 0:107), the violation of the inequality can hardly be attributed to (unavoidable but small) identification errors. In spite of this discrepancy, the model seems to provide a good fit for the experimental data (see, e.g., [8]).

In conclusion, we hope the analysis presented here provides some guidelines for the refinement of the basic LuGre model. To some extent, this has already been done in [7] and [8] where a passive modified model with a velocity-dependent coefficient 1 is proposed.
